choices.text: Let's see what I have on me...
I should SAVE my notes.
Should I just call it QUITs?
Nevermind.

pages.text: What now?

choices.text: Yeah, it's not my problem.
No. A girl's gone missing. I'm her only hope.

pages.text: Maybe I should forget about this whole business and just go home?

choices.text: My apartment.
The Alleycat.
Danni and Crystal's apartment.
The Lost Sock Laundromat.

pages.text: Where to?
Good to see you're still in possession of all your organs!

Hey man, you don't look like you're from around these parts.

This alleyway is one of the nicest in the Gutter, but if you go sticking your nose where it don't belong, you might end up an involuntary organ donor.

Lucky for you, I'm kind of a tour guide, and I don't need your organs. Name's Glitch, by the way.

choices.text: What's the Alleycat?
Where's good place to eat around here?
Do you know anything about a girl that went missing recently?
Let me put it another way, where could I get my hands on some Coral?
See you around.
Alright Glitch, I did what you asked. Now tell me the password.

pages.text: So, what do you want to know?
I'll be here if you need me.

choices.text: Figuratively or literally?

pages.text: Life is the only thing cheaper than the thrills at the Alleycat. If I were you, I'd be careful you don't get eaten alive.

choices.text: Why? What happened to him?

pages.text:
Takeshi's noodles was the best place, and just around the corner too. 

It's a shame he had to close up shop.
Both.

Ever the enterprising spirit, he decided to branch out.

Let's just say that ramen weren't the only noods he started selling, if you catch my drift. Made a few enemies.
Now his enterprising spirit probably haunts these alleyways...
Ok, listen up because I'm only going to say this once...
No.

choices.text: Why?

pages.text:
Coral? You don't look like you got the hardware to enjoy it, but who am I to judge.

Acid Nova's the only one selling it, and the Alleycat's the only place to find him. But good luck getting in.
They don't just let any scorched junkie in. You got to be vetted. Even if you had a ticket, you'd still need a password.

choices.text: I'll bite. Where can I get the password.
You have a bead on a ticket?
Let's talk about something else.

pages.text: Lucky for you, I have one and know where to find the other.

choices.text: Credits?

pages.text: That's the lucky part! I have the password and I'd be happy to scratch your back if you scratch mine. It'll be no problem, especially for you.

choices.text: You're a real Mother Theresa. What do you need me to do?

pages.text: Cred- what? No! No, nothing like that. Well, I guess it something like that. But I don't take money from people, there's so little of it to go around. Nah, I like to make the corpos bleed a little green, if you know what I mean.

choices.text: If it's so easy, why don't you do it?

pages.text: It's simple. All you have to do is take this magical credstick and let it do its voodoo in the cash machine nearby. That's all. Honest.

choices.text: Ok, fine. Give me the stick.

pages.text: *cough* Well, they got a tin-man standing in front of it and he's already got my scent. You, on the other hand, he doesn't know.

choices.text: Alright, seems simple enough.

pages.text: Alright, there's this guy Tweaker. He's a real chrome job and usually does business out by the subway. He can probably get you a ticket.

choices.text: Dyonisus, huh? Thanks.

pages.text:
And how! Man, that's a lot of credits...

Oh right! The password is Dyonisus. Good luck my friend, and if you need anything else, you just let me know!

choices.text: Let me in.

pages.text: What do you want, chump?

choices.text: Where do I get those?
I got a ticket.

pages.text: No ticket, no password: no entry. No exception.
Man, get drek out of my face!

choices.text: I don't know.
...Boobies?
Dionysus

pages.text: They just give these out to any drek these days. What's the password?
Get the drek out of my face!

choices.text: Steel. Blake Steel

pages.text: Very well, Mr...
Very well, Mr. Steel. Right this way.

choices.text: I need to use the jackpot.
Nevermind...

pages.text: *Ksssh* MOVE ALONG, CITIZEN. *Ksssh*

choices.text: What do you mean, "no?"
You're the boss.

pages.text: *Ksssh* NO. *Ksssh*

choices.text: I really need to get my money.
Please...?
Are you a dreking idiot?
No flaws with that logic, have a good evening.

pages.text: *Ksssh* I'M PROTECTING THIS CASH MACHINE. IF NOBODY USES IT, NOBODY CAN VANDELIZE IT. *Ksssh*
*Ksssh* THAT'S YOUR PROBLEM, NOW GET LOST *Ksssh*
*Ksssh* NO *Ksssh*

choices.text: Yes. I asked you if you're a dreking idiot.

pages.text: *Ksssh* DO YOU WANT TO SAY THAT AGAIN? *Ksssh*

choices.text: Think about it. How much money is the bank losing by you making it impossible to withdraw creds?

pages.text: *Ksssh* YOU HAVE TWO SECONDS TO GET OUT OF MY FACE BEFORE I REARRANGE YOURS *Ksssh*

choices.text: Well that's good! You saved them from paying for a coat of paint and only losing thousands in transaction fees.

pages.text: *Ksssh* ERR... AH... WELL... AT LEAST IT'S NOT GETTING VANDELIZED *Ksssh*

choices.text: Best case scenario, they shut this jackpot down because it brings in no money and you lose your job. Worst case, they sue you for lost revenue. Good luck.

pages.text: *Ksssh* YEAH, BUT... *Ksssh*

choices.text: Thank you.

pages.text: *Ksssh* FINE! FINE! YOU CAN USE IT, JUST BE QUICK *Ksssh*

choices.text: Are you Tweaker?
I got your noodles.
I'm asking.
Blake Steel, PI.
Glitch sent me.

pages.text: Depends on who's asking.

choices.text: Wait! Glitch sent me.

pages.text: Well, I have no idea who you are. Get lost.

choices.text: I'm here for business, Glitch sent me.

pages.text: A PI? You're one 'G' short.

choices.text: She said you could get me a ticket for the Alleycat.

pages.text: Glitch needs to keep her mouth shut. What do you want?

choices.text: A man... hmm... has needs.
I'm looking for someone.

pages.text: The Alleycat? They're going to eat you alive. What could someone like you possibly want with that pleasure palace?
*laughs* Good drecking luck with that.

choices.text: Danni Ashton. Heard of her?

pages.text: Who?

choices.text: I'll take that as a 'yes.' What happened to her?

pages.text: Ah shit.

choices.text: Thanks for your concern. Nonetheless, I need a ticket.

pages.text: Look man, the Alleycat swallows people whole, if you value your life, stay away.

choices.text: Try me.
You don't know what I can afford.

pages.text: Alright, let's say I had a ticket to sell you, you couldn't affort it.

choices.text: You just want some dreking noodles?

pages.text:
You can't afford it because what want you can't get.

Nobody's ever going to get any more of Takeshi's noods, on account of him mysteriously 404ing.

choices.text: I think you underestimate how resorceful I am.

pages.text:
Not just any noods! Takeshi's! The man was a master of his craft, and he alway left a small surprise printed on bottom of the bowls... heh heh...

Anyway, no Takeshi, no noods.

choices.text: I told you I am pretty resorceful. This is the last bowl in existence. So if you want it, I'll take one of those tickets.

pages.text: What?! How's that possible?!

choices.text: Pleasure doing business with ya.
What's the deal with the noodles anyway?

pages.text: You got a dreking deal! Here's your ticket. Hope you find what you're looking for.

choices.text: Gross. I'm out.

pages.text:
It's not about the noods themselves, but what's at the bottom of the bowl.

Takeshi's started printing nudes on the bottom of his bowls of noods! They're collector's items.
Oh great! You're back.

choices.text: The name's...

pages.text:
What do we have here?

No body armor, so you're no
cop. Ya got no hardware, so you're no chrome job.

So... who are you?
Nah, man. I'm keen to guess.

choices.text: Not even close.
I don't have time for this.

pages.text: You go door to door selling drek?

choices.text: Wrong again.
I've had enough of this drek.

pages.text: You're an out of luck ambulance chaser?

choices.text: It's like you're not even trying!
Look, I'm...

pages.text: You're the health inspector come to shut us down?

choices.text: Finally talking sense!
... the coat's not that cheap.

pages.text: Judging from your cheap trenchcoat, I'm guessing you're going to be a pain in my ass.

choices.text: The name's Blake. I heard you're the guy to talk to about Coral.
I'm a PI who's looking for a girl.
Just looking at you, I can tell this is going to be pointless. Bye.

pages.text: What do you want?

choices.text: People keep saying that. What in the drek are you talking about?

pages.text: What could you possibly want from Coral? You don't have the hardware to enjoy it.

choices.text: Why don't you educate me, then.

pages.text: You for real asking me for Coral when you clearly have no idea what it is?

choices.text: What is it, exactly?
Is it addictive?
How does one take it?
Where does it come from?
Actually, I wanted to talk to you about something else.

pages.text: Coral's a "simstim". It's a digital drug. You need hardware, you need cybernetics in order to partake, my unmodified friend.

choices.text: All that from a computer program? Huh.

pages.text: Exactly what I said. When you insert the coral in your socket, it downloads a program that parties on your neural interface. It messes with the signals that are coming from your cybernetics, giving you a full body high. You feel drek that isn't even happening. It shuts you down while you're chasing those ruby slippers so you don't go running around while stoned out of your mind.

choices.text: ... ergo, you can't get chemically dependent on it, right.

pages.text: It feels great but it's no more addictive than really good sex. Some people can't help themselves and will chase those ruby slippers. It's a simstim, there are no chemicals...

choices.text: But if it's just a program on a data chip, can't people copy it and put you out of a job?

pages.text: It's all in this little red chip. You plug into your socket and it does the rest.

choices.text: KryptoKool? What a stupid name.

pages.text: They say it's the brainchild of a biohacker by the name of KryptoKool. As for where I get it, well, I don't think we're close enough friends.

choices.text: ... Good to see that your retirement is secure.

pages.text: Your concern for my livelyhood is touching, it really is. But that's the clever bit. The data chip destroys itself when it downloads into you. Or if you tamper with it. It even deletes itself from your system after a random amount of time. Nah, this drek is clever.

choices.text: Look at this picture, you recognize her?

pages.text: Aren't we all?

choices.text: I thought we were just becoming friends and you have to lie to my face?

pages.text: ... never seen her in my life.

choices.text: Her name is Danni Ashton. She did Coral. You are the only Coral dealer in the Gutter.  I'm just trying to find her.

pages.text: How do you figure?

choices.text: Now listen here, you...
Really? Look at the photo again, she's not that forgettable.
Fine. How many credits will it take to jog your RAM?

pages.text: I don't keep track of every chrome job junkie that crosses my path. Get lost.

choices.text: This isn't over.

pages.text:
Let me stop you right there, while I'm still in a good mood. I don't like to be called a liar by a two-bit walking cliche with the aforementioned cheap coat. So you can drop this now and enjoy the delights the Alleycat has to offer, or I can ask Tank, who I believe you already met on your way in to show you the way out.

Am I coming through clear?

choices.text: It seems you have me at a disadvantage, miss...?
Ba... err.. uhm... oof... ah...

pages.text: Act natural, we're just two friends going for a walk. We can't afford to stick out.

choices.text: Yes.
Err... *cough* uhm, who? Oh right, yes. Yes I am.

pages.text: My name's Crystal. I overheard you talking to that skeez, Acid. Is it true what you said? That you're looking for Danni?

choices.text: I understand she went missing  a few days ago. I'm a private investigator and her father's paying me to find her.
Uhm... err... her father is, uhm looking for her. Is it me or is it getting unseasonably warm?

pages.text: Why? What's your angle?

choices.text: You know my interest in Danni, what about yours?
How do you, uh... how do you know her?

pages.text: Her father, huh? Danni never talks about her family.

choices.text: Do you know anything about what happened to her?

pages.text: Danni's a good friend of mine.

choices.text: What makes you so sure of that?

pages.text: I don't, but it's got to be something bad.

choices.text: When she didn't come home?
Do you, uhm, live together?

pages.text: These are dangerous times. We had a system: if one of use stayed out the night, we'd send a message the next morning that all was clear. When she didn't come home and didn't message, I knew something wasn't right.

choices.text: Room mates?! Can we head back to your place then?
Can we... go back to your place?

pages.text: Yes. We're room mates.

choices.text: What? No. I want to search her place, your place, for any clue or indication as to what could have happened.
*cough* Erm.. *blush* No... uh... I mean... *cough* uhm clues...

pages.text: You can't afford me, slick.

choices.text: You don't seem that defenceless to me. Lead the way.
But being funny is one of my strong suits. Oh well.

pages.text: Oh... right! That' makes sense. But don't try anything funny. I'm not as defenceless as I seem.

choices.text: Actually, could you tell me about Danni?
I found this note in her room, what do you make of it?
I found her id.
Nothing more for now.

pages.text: Have you found anything yet, Blake?

choices.text: How do you two meet?
What does Danni do for a living, exactly...
Has she ever mentioned her family to you?
Thanks, that was helpful.

pages.text: Sure, what do you want to know?

choices.text: What kind of shop?
I have other questions.

pages.text: We met two years ago. She came into... uh... the shop, looking for work. We started chatting and we've been friends ever since. Eventually we got this place together so that we wouldn't have to live in a dreking hole.

choices.text: I see... and where is this business?
Cyber courtesans, digital doxies, purchased paramours?

pages.text: Danni and I work for a business that caters to the *very expensive* tastes of very wealthy people. Particularly when those tastes have to do with companionship.
Don't be an ass, Blake. Everyone's doing what they can to survive.

choices.text: Hmm... I may have to have a chat with this Gladys.

pages.text: There's a laundromat called the "The Left Sock". While it's a real, functional, laundromat, it's actually a front for the real business. I don't know who runs it, but Gladys Aubergine is who both Danni and I report up to. She sends us on... assignments.

choices.text: Ugh... that was terrible. Anyway, a have a few more questions.

pages.text: I don't know... she may not be *snicker* "Gladys" to see you.

choices.text: It mentions someone named "15." Any idea who that is?

pages.text: It's a note from Gladys... Danni must have received this just before she went missing.

choices.text: Has she ever mentioned who he is?
15? That seems pretty impersonal.
A have a few more questions.

pages.text: 15... Danni mentioned him quite a few times. He's got a thing for her. I'd say three quarters of her assignments are with him.
Never. All I know is that he's a big spender. Whatever he wants, he gets.
As you can imagine, discression is very important in this business. Normally we use code names, and 15 chose his.
No, she never has. But to be fair, neither have I to her. Many people come to the Gutter to get away from their past.

choices.text: It's a long shot, but I still have access to a GovLink machine. If I run her ID, we might be able to turn something up.

pages.text: Her ID? How's that useful?

choices.text: Run Danni's ID card.
Run a Database Search.
Log off.

pages.text: What should I do?

choices.text: Nothing else.

pages.text: What should I search for?

choices.text: Hey girl, want a treat?
Who's a good girl?
Let me run some stuff by you, girl.
Ok, I got to get back to work

pages.text: Boof.

choices.text: Here you go, girl.

pages.text: Bark!

choices.text: That's right! You're a good girl!

pages.text: *Covers her face with her paws*

choices.text: Daisy, I was afraid I would not be a good dog parent but when you walked up to me the first time, I knew I had to try. I want to tell you that you've brought me immeasurable joy and happiness, that you're a ray of sunlight that pierces these dark clouds, that you stirred something in my heart that I never thought I'd feel. I want to tell you these things but I lack an adequate way to express it, so I'll do the best I can and give you all the hugs, walks, and treats that you can take.

It breaks me to think of a future without you, without your goofy smile or long walks, without the joy it brings me when you keep me company in my office or when you fall asleep at my feet. I hope you know how much I love you, even when I  make you get off the couch or keep you from eating my breakfast. I hope you know you left a big paw print on my heart that will never dull.
No matter what happens, I'll always be your dad. I love you sweetie.
Danni was an orphan and as she was never adopted, she was given the last name 'Null'. Two years ago, she reinvents herself as 'Danni Ashton'... that's about when she met Crystal.
Nevermind, how about a treat instead?

pages.text: *Cocks her head*

choices.text: But what bothers me is that if she chose the name 'Danni Ashton' for herself, then who the drek is 'Jacob', the man who hired me and posed as her concerned father?

pages.text: Boof.

choices.text: Exactly, something here stinks.

pages.text: Grrr...

regions.description: People having a good time. No gods, no kings, no rules.
Hmm... The bar looks fully stocked...
If you squint, the view is really nice.
